__data__.text: During the Argentine War of Independence and the Auxiliary Expeditions to Upper Peru, a tense climate existed between Peru, which remained loyal to the Spanish Crown, and the Junta de Buenos Aires, which sought independence for the Rio de la Plata and the spread of the May Revolution across South America. This led to military conflicts between Peruvian supporters of the counterrevolution and Argentine supporters of the revolution. At the height of these tensions, there were instances of anti-Peruvian sentiment due to the destruction caused by the Argentine troops, leading some Peruvians to reject the idea of having a direct border with Buenos Aires.

The Argentine government's execution of the leaders of the Córdoba Counterrevolution, who had backing from the Viceroyalty of Peru, was intended to intimidate Peru and demonstrate the junta's hostility towards those who opposed the revolution. This action, prompted by Mariano Moreno, was a warning to both Cordobans and Peruvians, highlighting the tense climate between Peru and the Junta de Buenos Aires during the Argentine War of Independence and the Auxiliary Expeditions to Upper Peru.

The Junta de Buenos Aires, in defense of the King's and the homeland's rights, has ordered the execution of the Córdoba conspirators, who were well-known for their crimes and condemned by the general vote of the good people. The accused, including Santiago Liniers, Juan Gutiérrez de la Concha, the Bishop of Córdoba, Victorino Rodríguez, Colonel Allende, and Royal Officer Joaquín Moreno, are sentenced to be shot. This action serves as a warning to both Cordobans and Peruvians, reflecting the tense relations between Peru and the Junta de Buenos Aires during the Argentine War of Independence and the Auxiliary Expeditions to Upper Peru.

The Junta de Buenos Aires, in support of the King's and homeland's rights, has decided to execute the Córdoba conspirators, including Victorino Rodríguez, Colonel Allende, and Royal Officer Joaquín Moreno, who were well-known for their crimes and condemned by the majority. This decision serves as a warning to both Cordobans and Peruvians, aiming to maintain stability and teach a lesson to Peruvian leaders, demonstrating the effectiveness and energy of the expedition in fulfilling its objectives. The accused will be shot whenever they are caught, without allowing time for pleas or explanations that could compromise the execution of this order and the Junta's honor.

The Junta de Buenos Aires has decided to execute several individuals, including Santiago Liniers, Juan Gutiérrez de la Concha, the Bishop of Córdoba, Victorino Rodríguez, Colonel Allende, and Joaquin Moreno, in order to uphold the King's rights and maintain stability. This decision is intended to serve as a warning to people in Córdoba and Peru, and to demonstrate the effectiveness of the expedition. The accused will be punished immediately upon capture, without delay or the opportunity to make appeals, in order to preserve the honor of the Junta. This action is meant to establish order in the new system and set an example for Peruvian leaders.

The Argentine members of the Junta, influenced by Peruvian-phobia, presented a proposal to the Congress of Tucumán on July 6, 1816, suggesting the establishment of a ceremonial monarchy. They discussed the possibility of selecting a European prince, and then considered Peruvian rulers from the Inca lineage, with Juan Bautista Túpac Amaru, the surviving brother of Túpac Amaru II, as the leading candidate. Other potential choices included Dionisio Inca Yupanqui, a mestizo jurist and soldier educated in Europe, and Juan Andrés Jiménez de León Manco Cápac, a mestizo cleric and soldier known for his opposition to excessive tribute collection and his participation in Juan José Castelli's uprising. This proposal aimed to demonstrate the Junta's power and intentions to the Peruvian leaders and people.

The Argentine Junta, driven by Peruvian-phobia, proposed a ceremonial monarchy four days after declaring Argentina's independence on July 6, 1816. They suggested a European prince or a Peruvian ruler from the Inca lineage, such as Juan Bautista Túpac Amaru, Dionisio Inca Yupanqui, or Juan Andrés Jiménez de León Manco Cápac. The proposed government would be similar to the British parliamentary system and have its capital in Cuzco. However, this idea was met with ridicule and rejection, particularly from the Buenos Aires delegates who opposed serving a "king with flip flops." The proposal was rejected due to anti-Peruvian racism, and the Buenos Aires journalists mocked the decision, suggesting that the king would have to be found in a grocery store or tavern in the Altiplano.

The Argentine Congress, influenced by anti-Peruvian sentiments, rejected the idea of a ceremonial Incan monarchy and established a republican government in Buenos Aires instead. This was not the only display of anti-Peruvianism, as the Buenos Aires government also sponsored privateer William Brown to attack Peruvian and Chilean ports, aiming to harm Spanish trade. The main target was the Port of Callao, which was attacked in January 1816. Despite some royalists' attempts to inform Chile for defense, José de San Martín intercepted these communications.

In January 1816, Argentine corsairs, led by William Brown, targeted the Port of Callao, one of their main objectives. Brown's fleet, consisting of four ships and a pailebot, approached the port near the Rimac River on January 22nd. Despite the presence of castles, Brown's forces displayed insolence, suggesting they were aware of the lack of armed ships in the port. They exchanged cannon fire, damaging one of the anchored frigates, the Fuente-Hermosa, before withdrawing until midnight, when they returned to attack and ultimately sink the Fuente-Hermosa.

The Argentine corsairs, led by William Brown, showed hostility towards the Peruvian population, causing some Peruvian travelers to prefer land routes via the Amazon to avoid them. Additionally, certain historians have suggested that the Argentine Liberator, Jose de San Martin, may have held anti-Peruvian sentiments, questioning whether an outsider would declare Peru's independence, which was seen as imposed and possibly against the will of the Peruvians, rather than achieved or conceived by them. This perspective aligns with the historiographical thesis of independence granted, not achieved or conceived.

San Martin is perceived to have negative feelings towards Peru, as indicated by his statement about the need for Bolivar and force to liberate the country. His desire to give Upper Peru to the United Provinces of Río de la Plata, along with his ambiguous promises to Peruvian politicians, has led to accusations of dishonesty and anti-Peruvianism. This is consistent with the idea that Peru's independence was granted, not achieved or conceived by its own people.

San Martin's actions and statements created mistrust among Peruvians, with suspicion and fear that he aimed to take over Upper Peru, Arequipa, and Cuzco. His monarchical project through the Protectorate of San Martin was viewed as hypocritical, as he was accused of favoring European princes over existing Peruvian institutions, imitating English and French constitutionalism, and disregarding monarchical proposals that represented indigenous nobility's interests. This led to accusations of him being Anglophile, Frenchified, and a Criollo elitist. Overall, Peru's independence was seen as granted, not achieved or conceived by its own people, with San Martin perceived to have negative feelings towards Peru.

In the Cajamarca region, the indigenous nobility proposed that the new Peruvian state's government should be led by a descendant of Atahualpa, specifically Don Manuel Soto Astopilco, and suggested the revival of the Tahuantinsuyo State with a claim to the crown. They approached Torre Tagle with this proposal after learning about Peru's sworn independence. However, San Martin's government did not respond to this request. This event showcases the desire of some Peruvians to have a say in their government and resistance to San Martin's monarchical project, which was perceived as favoring European principles over existing Peruvian institutions.

The indigenous nobility in Cajamarca suggested that a descendant of Atahualpa, Don Manuel Soto Astopilco, should lead the new Peruvian state's government and advocated for the Tahuantinsuyo State's revival. However, San Martin's government did not respond to this proposal, demonstrating the Creole oligarchy's lack of interest in indigenous political society and a disregard for considering Inca successors in any alternative government. This event highlights the desire of some Peruvians to have a say in their government and resistance to San Martin's monarchical project, which was perceived as favoring European principles over existing Peruvian institutions.

The Creole oligarchy in the Trujillo Intendancy showed little interest in incorporating the indigenous political society, as seen in their rejection of considering Inca successors for government. This attitude hinted that any new government, whether monarchy or republic, would be led by the Criollo elite, not indigenous people. San Martin's intentions of independence faced obstacles not only from Simon Bolivar's intervention and opposition from some Peruvians but also from the negative impact of Bernardo de Monteagudo's extreme views, which damaged the emancipation of America.

Following Peru's independence, Bernardo de Monteagudo implemented resolutions from December 1821 to February 1822, targeting unbaptized peninsular Spaniards with measures such as expulsion, asset confiscation, and commerce restrictions. These actions led to the departure of an estimated 10,000 to 12,000 Spaniards, with Monteagudo himself expelling around 4,000. This severe treatment is considered by historian Timothy E. Anna as an exceptional act of violence and human rights abuse, further complicating the emancipation of America.

Post-independence, Bernardo de Monteagudo's resolutions from late 1821 to early 1822 targeted unbaptized peninsular Spaniards through expulsion, asset confiscation, and commerce restrictions, causing around 10,000 to 12,000 Spaniards to leave Peru. This extreme treatment is viewed by historian Timothy E. Anna as an "unparalleled act of violence and unprecedented human rights abuse," contributing to the complexities of America's emancipation. Monteagudo's actions were met with resentment by the Lima population, who saw it as an unfair abuse of long-term Spanish residents with significant social and economic roles. Notably, his measures threatened the merchant class, which played a crucial part in agriculture and mining, as both large, small, and medium-sized owners were expropriated indiscriminately. Additionally, Argentine battalions were reported to have caused disturbances on local farms, further fueling civil unrest.

After Peru's independence, Bernardo de Monteagudo implemented harsh policies against unbaptized peninsular Spaniards, leading to the expulsion, asset confiscation, and commerce restrictions of around 10,000 to 12,000 Spaniards. This extreme treatment is considered a severe act of violence and human rights abuse by historian Timothy E. Anna. Monteagudo's actions faced backlash from the Lima population, who saw it as an unfair abuse of long-term Spanish residents with significant social and economic roles.

Moreover, Argentine battalions caused disturbances on local farms, damaging crops and injuring peasants, which added to the civil unrest. According to the revisionist perspective, these measures would have been permitted by San Martín, who aimed to benefit the United Provinces of the Río de la Plata by weakening Peru's economic base. This did not occur in Chile and Argentina, revealing regional economic power rivalries in Latin America, with Chileans and Argentines having conflicting feelings and interests towards their Peruvian counterparts, including the Inca nobility for their royalist tendencies.

Post-Peruvian independence, José de San Martín and his minister Bernardo Monteagudo adopted harsh policies, disregarding Peruvian civilization and democratic prospects. Monteagudo prioritized eliminating the Spanish threat in Chile and La Plata, leading to the expropriation and squandering of Lima's mercantile elite, damaging local confidence and property rights. Chileans and Argentines, whose states financed the liberation with their bourgeoisie's contributions, had conflicting feelings and interests compared to Peruvians, including the Inca nobility due to their royalist leanings, rather than fostering a united Spanish-American front against imperialism. These actions did not result in Peru's definitive independence.

After Peru's independence, San Martín and Monteagudo implemented strict policies, focusing on eliminating the Spanish threat in Chile and La Plata. This led to the confiscation and misuse of Lima's mercantile elite properties, damaging the economy, local trust, and property rights. The confiscated assets were primarily in the central coast region, valued at about two million pesos, and mainly given to military officers as compensation, such as Sucre, O'Higgins, Echenique, Ryes, Sardeña, and Plaza. Corrupt local officials continued these abuses in the provinces. To worsen the situation, Admiral Cochrane, unpaid for his naval services, took silver reserves accumulated by San Martín's government and benefited from capturing Peruvian merchant ships.

Post-independence, San Martín and Monteagudo's stringent policies targeting the Spanish threat in Chile and La Plata resulted in the confiscation and misuse of properties from Lima's mercantile elite, negatively impacting the economy, local trust, and property rights. This issue was exacerbated by Admiral Cochrane's corruption, who, unpaid for his naval services, took silver reserves and benefited from capturing Peruvian merchant ships.

In the context of forming the State of Alto Peru, there was opposition in Argentina towards Peru, as they feared its aggrandizement due to its historical commercial and military influence. This, along with the corrupt distribution of official positions and internal strife among the new separatist authorities, contributed to the weak organizational bases and provided an environment for corruption and abuse of power. Diplomats from France noted the lack of popular support for independence because of this corruption and infighting.

After independence, corruption and infighting among separatist authorities in Peru, including the misuse of properties from Lima's elite and Admiral Cochrane's corruption, led to a lack of popular support for independence. In the context of the War in Brazil, Peru and Bolivia were expected to support Argentina, potentially at the expense of their own interests. Tensions between the Peru-Bolivian Confederation and the Argentine Confederation had already been high due to Bolivian President Santa Cruz's support for unitary groups in Argentina. In response, the Argentine government, led by Rosas, closed all communication between the Argentine and Peruvian-Bolivian Confederations in February 1837, effectively breaking off diplomatic relations.

Following Peru's independence, corruption and infighting among separatist leaders, including Admiral Cochrane, undermined support for independence. Although Argentina and the Peru-Bolivian Confederation were not formally linked, tensions were high due to Bolivian President Santa Cruz's backing of unitary groups in Argentina. In February 1837, the Argentine government under Rosas severed communication with the Peruvian-Bolivian Confederation, signifying a break in relations. Although Rosas was not inherently anti-Peruvian, his concerns about Peru's growing power, as expressed in the Manifiesto de las razones, suggest an element of anti-Peruvian sentiment in Argentina's actions.

After Peru's independence, tensions between Peru and Argentina arose due to concerns about Peru's growing power and its support for unitary groups in Argentina. These tensions were exacerbated by Peru's opposition to Argentina's role in the War of the Triple Alliance, which Peru saw as an attempt to conquer and divide Paraguay. The Peruvian government viewed the Secret Treaty of the Triple Alliance as a violation of Paraguay's sovereignty, and perceived Argentina negatively as a result. This animosity was fueled by Bolivian fears of being dominated by Peru, as expressed in the Manifiesto de las razones, which questioned whether there would be a balance of power between Peru and Bolivia, and warned of the dangers of fusion under a conqueror. Overall, the text suggests that there were elements of anti-Peruvian sentiment in Argentina's actions, and that Peru was wary of Argentina's potential expansionist ambitions.

Post-independence, Peru was critical of the Secret Treaty of the Triple Alliance, viewing it as a violation of Paraguay's sovereignty and comparing it to European imperialism. This perspective was influenced by Pan-Americanism, which promoted continental solidarity and defense of national sovereignty. Peru was particularly wary of potential expansionist ambitions from Argentina, which was seen as having negative intentions towards Peru and Paraguay. This aligns with the text's suggestion of anti-Peruvian sentiment in Argentina's actions and Peru's wariness of Argentina's potential imperialism.

Post-independence, Peru's diplomacy was shaped by Pan-Americanism, emphasizing continental solidarity and defense of sovereignty, particularly against perceived expansionist threats from Brazil and Argentina. This was evident in their criticism of the Triple Alliance's actions towards Paraguay. Peru's support for Paraguay led to Argentina adopting anti-Peruvian positions, including refusing to join the Quadruple Alliance against Spain in the Chincha Islands War. The Triple Alliance also tried to divide the Pacific governments and weaken the Quadruple Alliance, with Bolivia being a key target for Argentine diplomacy.

After Peru's independence, its diplomacy centered on Pan-Americanism, focusing on continental unity and sovereignty defense, especially against Brazil and Argentina. This stance led to Peru backing Paraguay, which strained relations with Argentina. In this context, Argentina and Uruguay attempted to sway Bolivia, viewing it as a prime opportunity due to its territorial disputes with Peru and Chile. Argentine diplomacy, perceiving Peru's involvement in Paraguay's affairs as less significant than Chile's, prioritized Bolivia, casting Peru as subservient to Chilean interests. This discriminatory approach highlights Argentina's diplomatic strategy against Peru during this period.

Post-independence Peruvian diplomacy emphasized Pan-Americanism and defense against Brazil and Argentina, causing strained relations with Argentina due to Peru's support for Paraguay. Argentina, in turn, tried to influence Bolivia, seeing it as a chance to counter Peru and Chile. Argentine diplomats accused Chile of interfering in Bolivia, supporting actions against Argentina. Meanwhile, opposing governments in Argentina and Uruguay restricted dissident press favoring Chile and Peru, while pro-Spanish immigrant newspapers with anti-Peru and anti-Chile biases circulated freely. This illustrates the discriminatory diplomatic approach Argentina took towards Peru during this time. Both El Mercurio of Valparaíso and La Nación Argentina of Buenos Aires, linked to their countries' elites, shared a commitment to economic and political liberalism, but the latter showed biases against Peru and Chile.

In the post-independence period, both El Mercurio of Valparaíso and La Nación Argentina of Buenos Aires, representing their countries' elites, advocated for economic and political liberalism. However, they differed in their interpretation of Americanism. El Mercurio strongly supported Pan-American solidarity without discrimination, while La Nación adopted a condescending attitude, dividing countries into "civilized" and "barbaric" categories. La Nación, viewing itself as "civilized," expressed disdain towards Peru and Paraguay, justifying its actions against them and the repression of conservative uprisings. This bias also reflected the Argentine elite's Eurocentric views and social Darwinism, which looked down upon non-white societies, including Peru and the mestizo heritage in Latin America. This summary highlights the contrasting perspectives of the two newspapers and their underlying prejudices in their diplomatic approach.

In the post-independence period, El Mercurio and La Nación represented their countries' elites, advocating for economic and political liberalism but differing in their interpretation of Americanism. El Mercurio promoted Pan-American solidarity without discrimination, while La Nación adopted a condescending attitude, dividing countries into "civilized" and "barbaric" categories, expressing disdain towards Peru and Paraguay due to their non-white or mestizo heritage. This prejudice was reflected in later incidents, such as when Argentine dictator Jorge Rafael Videla attempted to psychologically intimidate the Peruvian soccer team during the 1978 FIFA World Cup, and when the Peruvian foreign minister, José de la Puente, was cautious about forming a military alliance with Argentina in 1978 due to historical tensions, alluding to Argentina's past expansionism at Peru's expense.

In the 20th century, due to the substantial presence of undocumented Peruvian immigrants in Argentina, the two countries agreed to a Reciprocal Migration Agreement in 1998 to regularize their status, granting a 180-day period. The agreement acknowledged the rights of Peruvian workers in Argentina for up to 12 months, after which they had to comply with the Argentine Immigration Law, which was criticized as xenophobic and racist by the opposition, the Church, and various sectors. The Commission of Peruvian Ladies Resident in Argentina, led by Mrs. Carmen Steimann, advocated for the Peruvian community in Buenos Aires, denouncing the Argentine gendarmerie's harsh and discriminatory treatment towards Peruvian and Bolivian immigrants.

In the 20th century, due to a large number of undocumented Peruvian immigrants in Argentina, a Reciprocal Migration Agreement was established in 1998 to regulate their status. However, the Argentine Immigration Law was criticized for being xenophobic and racist. The Commission of Peruvian Ladies Resident in Argentina, led by Carmen Steimann, advocated for Peruvian immigrants' rights, denouncing harsh and discriminatory treatment by the Argentine gendarmerie. Steimann accused the gendarmerie of obsessively and cruelly persecuting Peruvian and Bolivian immigrants. Relations between Argentina and Peru were strained, particularly during Carlos Menem's presidency, due to arms sales to Ecuador during its war with Peru. This led to accusations of anti-Peruvian attitudes and treason. Diplomatic relations remained frozen until 2010, when Argentina expressed reparations to Peru. However, some Peruvian newspapers believed that Cristina Fernández's actions did not fully address the moral claims of Peruvian society, raising suspicions of possible anti-Peruvian conduct.

The text discusses instances of perceived anti-Peruvian attitudes in Argentina, as reflected in the media. In 2000, the magazine La Primera claimed a "Silent Invasion" of Peruvians and Bolivians, using a manipulated image to emphasize the message. In 2010, the newspaper La Nación reported on an alleged invasion of Bolivians, Peruvians, and Paraguayans, which sparked xenophobic and racist comments from readers. During Cristina Fernández's presidency, her cautious remarks about arms sales to Ecuador were criticized in the Correo (using the headline "He did not ask for forgiveness") and Peru 21 (which felt she "almost asked for forgiveness"). These examples suggest a history of negative sentiment towards Peruvians in Argentina.

The text mentions additional instances of negative sentiment towards Peruvians in Argentina, this time from certain political sectors. In 2010, Justicialist senator Miguel Ángel Pichetto made controversial statements suggesting that Peruvians were responsible for crime and drug problems in Argentina. The government at the time agreed with his statements, which caused further controversy. Pichetto's anti-Peruvian remarks caused concern among Peruvian diplomats in 2019 when he was nominated for the Argentine vice presidency. In 2020, he made similar statements, referring to the Buenos Aires suburbs as a "social adjustment" of several South American countries, including Peru. These instances indicate a pattern of negative attitudes towards Peruvians in Argentina, similar to those observed in the media.

In 2020, Miguel Ángel Pichetto made remarks linking the social issues of Buenos Aires to Peruvians, Bolivians, Paraguayans, and Venezuelans. This is part of a historical pattern of Argentines expressing negative sentiments towards Peruvians and other nationalities, often using them as scapegoats in political discourse. Similarly, relations between Peru and Bolivia have been fraught with tension and mistrust, with both sides holding negative stereotypes and perceptions of each other, dating back to the Battle of Ingavi and the War of the Pacific.

The historical actions, including Bolivia's attempts to appropriate territories from Peru in 1826, have contributed to the formation of Bolivia's national identity with negative sentiments towards Peru. This is evident in Bolivia's early efforts to claim lands such as Arica, Tacna, and Tarapacá, as outlined in the Pact of Chuquisaca. However, these attempts were met with resistance from Peru, leading to tensions and mistrust between the two nations. This longstanding pattern of negative sentiment and actions has helped shape the national identities and perceptions of both countries.

The text indicates that Bolivia has had negative feelings towards Peru, as seen in their historical attempts to claim Peruvian territories like Arica and Tacna. This is further shown in Bolivia's efforts to overturn a decree that made Arica Peruvian, but they were unsuccessful. Additionally, there is a belief in Bolivia that Peru betrayed them during the War against the Peru-Bolivian Confederation due to nationalist sentiments, and that Peruvians opposed the union to avoid being governed by a Bolivian leader. These actions and perceptions have contributed to the shaping of the national identities and attitudes of both countries.

The text suggests that during the War against the Peru-Bolivian Confederation, Bolivians were against the confederate project as they believed it favored Peru, creating two Peruvian states and giving Bolivia one vote out of three in decisions, which caused dissatisfaction. The Bolivians also accused their leader, Santa Cruz, of being too friendly with Peru, fueling anti-Peruvian sentiment. Furthermore, anti-Peruvian attitudes were present in liberal groups before, during, and after the War of the Pacific, often tied to anti-militarism. These attitudes have contributed to the development of national identities and feelings in both countries.

During the War against the Peru-Bolivian Confederation, Bolivian conservatives or pacifists aimed for a swift peace agreement with Chile, even if it meant criticizing Peruvians. This was demonstrated by Justiniano Sotomayor Guzmán's letters suggesting that Bolivia had a better ally in Chile and a worse enemy in Peru. After Bolivia's alliance with Peru in 1873, there were Bolivian political factions with pro-Chilean and anti-Peruvian sentiments, wanting to abandon Peru and cede Arica to Chile to regain autonomy and access to the sea. These attitudes contributed to the formation of national identities and feelings in both countries.

In the context of the War against the Peru-Bolivian Confederation, anti-Peruvian sentiments arose in Bolivia during the Question of Tacna and Arica. This was due to Bolivia's belief in their moral right to claim Arica as their sea outlet and their rejection of Peru's claims to recover Tacna and Arica without granting Bolivia a port. These feelings led to the development of derogatory remarks towards the Peruvian community in La Paz and influenced Bolivia's foreign policy. For instance, Bolivia secretly negotiated with Chile in 1895, agreeing that Tacna and Arica would be transferred to Bolivia after Chile's control ended. From 1902, they covertly discussed a peace agreement without a coastline, culminating in the 1904 treaty where Bolivia ceded their coastline to Chile in exchange for concessions, money, and a railroad to La Paz under Chilean administration, effectively preventing Peru from regaining Arica. In 1919, Bolivia even requested the League of Nations, through France, to seize Tacna and Arica.

During the War against the Peru-Bolivian Confederation, anti-Peruvian sentiments in Bolivia grew due to disagreements about Tacna and Arica. This led to hostility towards Peruvians in Bolivia and impacted foreign policy, with Bolivia secretly negotiating with Chile in 1895 and 1902, ultimately ceding their coastline in the 1904 treaty. In the 1900s and 1930s, the Bolivian press and politicians spread anti-Peruvian propaganda, even asking the League of Nations to seize Tacna and Arica. In 1975, Bolivia and Chile discussed a maritime corridor, but it couldn't be realized due to Peru's limited sovereignty over Arica, as established by the 1929 Treaty.

After the War against the Peru-Bolivian Confederation, anti-Peruvian sentiments in Bolivia increased due to disputes over Tacna and Arica, impacting foreign policy and resulting in Bolivia secretly collaborating with Chile in the early 1900s, culminating in the cession of their coastline in the 1904 treaty. Later, Bolivia sought help from the League of Nations to take control of Tacna and Arica. In 1975, Chile and Bolivia attempted to establish a maritime corridor, but this was not possible while the 1929 Treaty was in effect, which gave Peru limited sovereignty over Arica and required consultation before any changes to the territory's sovereignty. This situation led to the suspicion of an anti-Peruvian alliance between Chile and Bolivia against a potential military alliance between Peru and Argentina during the Cold War. Although the divide between pro-Peruvians and pro-Chileans in Bolivia has lessened, the media continues to use the issue of Bolivia's access to the sea as a distraction from other political issues, even if it involves anti-Peruvian narratives.

The history of Bolivian politics has shown anti-Peruvian tendencies, such as those of Andrés de Santa Cruz. Santa Cruz had conflicting geopolitical visions due to his highland nationalism, desiring both the reunification of Upper and Lower Peru, while also considering dividing Peru into two states for Bolivia's advantage. He envisioned Bolivia as a leading power in the continent, which he referred to as the "Macedonia of America," aiming to diminish the historical influence of Lima and Cuzco. Santa Cruz's dreams of power fluctuated between the image of legendary Incas bringing peace and progress to the coast and the ideal of a Greater Peru, with Bolivia as a dominant force.

Santa Cruz's political aspirations evolved to include the idea of a "Greater Peru" or "pan-Peru," with Bolivia serving as a leading power, akin to the "Macedonia of America." His ultimate goal was to establish a strong, united Peru, known as the Confederation, with him as its head. However, if confronted with defeat and humiliation, he would settle for a divided or weakened Peru, with one part potentially falling under Bolivia's influence. Following 1839, his focus shifted solely to Bolivia, leading him to view Peru as an adversary.

After the collapse of the Peruvian-Bolivian Confederation, Santa Cruz, Orbegoso, and their allies sought refuge in Ecuador, where they plotted to undermine the Peruvian government. Santa Cruz, still holding onto power in Bolivia, developed plans to weaken Peru and potentially annex its southern region to Bolivia. He also aimed to foster an alliance between Ecuador and New Granada to launch an attack on Peru. His disillusionment with Peru led him to view the country as an adversary, further emphasizing his exclusive focus on Bolivia and Ecuador.

Following the collapse of the Peruvian-Bolivian Confederation, Santa Cruz and his allies, residing in Ecuador, aimed to undermine the Peruvian government and instigate conflict. A key aspect of their strategy was to establish an alliance between Ecuador and New Granada to challenge Peru. This objective is reflected in Ecuador's sudden territorial claims on Peruvian regions such as Tumbes, Jaén, and Maynas, which had not been a point of contention previously. The incitement for these claims can be traced back to Santa Cruz and other adversaries of the Peruvian government who were seeking refuge in Ecuador. This shift in Ecuador's stance towards Peru can be attributed to the influence of Santa Cruz and his disillusionment with Peru, which led to the territorial disputes starting in 1841.

In the aftermath of the Peruvian-Bolivian Confederation's collapse, Santa Cruz and his allies in Ecuador attempted to destabilize the Peruvian government and provoke conflict. A crucial part of their plan was to forge an alliance between Ecuador and New Granada to challenge Peru, leading Ecuador to make territorial claims on Peruvian regions like Tumbes, Jaén, and Maynas. These claims arose due to the influence of Santa Cruz and his discontent with Peru.

Similarly, after the War between Peru and Bolivia, Bolivian leader José Ballivián adopted an anti-Peruvian policy, exploiting post-war sentiment. However, his popularity waned, and even the congress declined to declare war again in 1847. Ballivián conspired against the Peruvian government, issued debased Bolivian currency, "el feble," detrimental to Peruvian traders in the Altiplano, prohibited Peruvian exports, and collaborated with Peruvian José Felix Ugayn to develop a separatist project aimed at annexing southern Peru to Bolivia.

Post-Peruvian-Bolivian Confederation, Santa Cruz and allies in Ecuador tried to undermine the Peruvian government and instigate conflict. A key part of their strategy was to create an alliance between Ecuador and New Granada to challenge Peru, resulting in Ecuador laying claim to Peruvian territories like Tumbes, Jaén, and Maynas due to Santa Cruz's influence.

After the War between Peru and Bolivia, Bolivian leader José Ballivián adopted an anti-Peruvian stance, exploiting post-war sentiment. He conspired against the Peruvian government, released devalued Bolivian currency, "el feble," negatively affecting Peruvian traders in the Altiplano, banned Peruvian exports, and cooperated with Peruvian José Felix Ugayn to establish a separatist project aimed at annexing southern Peru to Bolivia (specifically Moquegua, Tacna, Arica, and Tarapacá).

Later, under Mariano Melgarejo, Bolivia's relations with Peru stabilized with the Arequipa Treaty of November 1848. However, during border negotiations with Chile, Melgarejo considered a proposal by Aniceto Vergara that would have harmed Peru by giving its coastline to Chile in exchange for military aid to annex Tacna and Arica, then owned by Peru and desired by Bolivia. Melgarejo also consistently displayed a secessionist attitude towards Peru and the Treaty of Alliance. Julio Méndez criticizes Melgarejo's anti-Peruvian stance, attributing it to "Austrian intrigues of Chile."

Julio Méndez accuses Melgarejo of being anti-Peruvian, citing "Austrian intrigues of Chile" as the reason for his desire to break the treaty. Carlos Walker Martínez describes Melgarejo's frequent drunken speeches about wanting to go to war with Peru and reconquer lost territories. Aniceto Arce, a member of the Liberal Party, supports English capitalists' interests and holds an anti-Peruvian stance, stating that Bolivia's salvation lies in aligning with Chilean conquests.

Julio Méndez, Carlos Walker Martínez, and Aniceto Arce express negative views towards Peru. Méndez attributes Melgarejo's intention to break the treaty to "Austrian intrigues of Chile," and Martínez mentions Melgarejo's frequent intoxicated speeches about wanting to go to war with Peru. Arce, a Liberal Party member, supports English capitalists' interests and believes Bolivia's salvation is through aligning with Chilean conquests. This is echoed by René Gabriel Moreno, a writer from Santa Cruz, who defends Arce's anti-Peruvian stance and criticizes a former president for advocating for war while Peru was making war efforts as an ally.
